column6: An introduction to the Italian language in the context of Italian culture.
A continuation of the introduction to the Italian language in the context of Italian culture.
Exposure to basic grammar and to current Italian useful to travelers. Not applicable to fulfillment of foreign language requirement.
Continued development of speaking, listening, reading and writing skills using a variety of cultural materials.
For residence and/or field research in an Italian-speaking community. Prior to registering for this course student must obtain departmental approval. Repeatable for a total of 6 hours.
Study and practice of written and oral Italian with emphasis on acquisition of written and oral proficiency in the language.
Advanced practice in speaking and writing the Italian language.
A survey of Italian literature from its medieval origins to the Baroque period.
This course surveys the major movements and authors from the Baroque period through the 20th century.
Lectures, readings, oral and written reports on outstanding features of the culture and civilization of Italy.
Variable topic course deals with single literary theme in Italian literature or a single author. May be offered in Italian or in English translation.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of Italian studies. S u graded.

column4: ITAL 25202 and junior standing and special approval.
column6: Allows the advanced, serious student to carry out research study project on Italian literature, language or culture. Prior approval of supervising faculty member department required. Repeatable for a total of 6 hours.

column4: 6 hours of Italian at the 30000- level.
column6: This course studies Dante's Divine Comedy in its entirety (Inferno, Purgatory and Paradise) in the original language.
